p: Luo et al. [ 16] reported in 1985 that both cats and rodents might be related to the spread of HFRS, while cat owners were more likely to develop HFRS, probably because the rodents infestation were more serious in the cat owners’ home. Meanwhile, dogs had also been reported to be naturally infected with HFRS virus [ 13], thus stratified analyses were conducted in this study to explore the individual and joint effects of raising cats and presence of rats at home, as well as the individual and joint effects of raising cats and raising dogs. All pairs were divided into case group and control group, with sex ( p > 0.05) and age ( p > 0.05) comparable between groups.
